name: DateFormat

unions.name: Token
unions.comment: These are the available tokens to help you format dates.

aliases.name: FormatOptions
aliases.comment:
These are the available options for formatting our dates.

Here's an example for creating Spanish `FormatOptions`:

    spanishFullMonthName : Time.Month -> String
    spanishFullMonthName month =
        case month of
            Jan ->
                "Enero"

            Feb ->
                "Febrero"

            Mar ->
                "Marzo"

            Apr ->
                "Abril"

            May ->
                "Mayo"

            Jun ->
                "Junio"

            Jul ->
                "Julio"

            Aug ->
                "Agosto"

            Sep ->
                "Septiembre"

            Oct ->
                "Octubre"

            Nov ->
                "Noviembre"

            Dec ->
                "Diciembre"

    spanishDayOfWeekName : Time.Weekday -> String
    spanishDayOfWeekName weekday =
        case weekday of
            Mon ->
                "Lunes"

            Tue ->
                "Martes"

            Wed ->
                "Miércoles"

            Thu ->
                "Jueves"

            Fri ->
                "Viernes"

            Sat ->
                "Sábado"

            Sun ->
                "Domingo"

    spanishOptions : DateFormat.FormatOptions
    spanishOptions =
        { fullMonthName = spanishFullMonthName
        , dayOfWeekName = spanishDayOfWeekName
        }
aliases.type: { fullMonthName : Time.Month -> String.String, dayOfWeekName : Time.Weekday -> String.String }

values.name: amPmLowercase
values.comment:
Get the AM / PM value of the hour, in uppercase.

Examples: `am, pm`

values.name: amPmUppercase
values.comment:
Get the AM / PM value of the hour, in uppercase.

Examples: `AM, PM`

values.name: dayOfMonthFixed
values.comment:
Get the numeric value of the day of the month, fixed to two places.

Examples: `01, 02, 03, ... 30, 31`

values.name: dayOfMonthNumber
values.comment:
Get the numeric value of the day of the month.

Examples: `1, 2, 3, ... 30, 31`

values.name: dayOfMonthSuffix
values.comment:
Get the numeric value of the day of the month, with a suffix at the end.

Examples: `1st, 2nd, 3rd, ... 30th, 31st`

values.name: dayOfWeekNameFirstThree
values.comment:
Gets the name of the day of the week, but just the first three letters.

Examples: `Sun, Mon, Tue, ... Fri, Sat`

values.name: dayOfWeekNameFirstTwo
values.comment:
Gets the name of the day of the week, but just the first two letters.

Examples: `Su, Mo, Tu, ... Fr, Sa`

values.name: dayOfWeekNameFull
values.comment:
Gets the full name of the day of the week.

Examples: `Sunday, Monday, ... Friday, Saturday`

values.name: dayOfWeekNumber
values.comment:
Get the numeric value of the day of the week.

Examples: `0, 1, 2, ... 5, 6`

values.name: dayOfWeekSuffix
values.comment:
Get the numeric value of the day of the week, with a suffix at the end.

Examples: `0th, 1st, 2nd, ... 5th, 6th`

values.name: dayOfYearFixed
values.comment:
Get the numeric value of the day of the year, fixed to three places.

Examples: `001, 002, 003, ... 364, 365`

values.name: dayOfYearNumber
values.comment:
Get the numeric value of the day of the year.

Examples: `1, 2, 3, ... 364, 365`

values.name: dayOfYearSuffix
values.comment:
Get the numeric value of the day of the year, with a suffix at the end.

Examples: `1st, 2nd, 3rd, ... 364th, 365th`

values.name: format
values.comment:
This function takes in a list of tokens, [`Zone`](/packages/elm-lang/time/latest/Time#Zone), and [`Posix`](/packages/elm-lang/time/latest/Time#Posix) to create your formatted string!

Let's say `ourPosixValue` is November 15, 1993 at 15:06.

    -- "15:06"
    format
        [ hourMilitaryFixed
        , text ":"
        , minuteFixed
        ]
        utc
        ourPosixValue

    -- "3:06 pm"
    format
        [ hourNumber
        , text ":"
        , minuteFixed
        , text " "
        , amPmLowercase
        ]
        utc
        ourPosixValue

    -- "Nov 15th, 1993"
    format
        [ monthNameFirstThree
        , text " "
        , dayOfMonthSuffix
        , text ", "
        , yearNumber
        ]
        utc
        ourPosixValue

values.name: formatWithOptions
values.comment:
If our users don't speak English, printing out "Monday" or "Tuesday" might not be a great fit.

Thanks to a great recommendation, `date-format` now supports multilingual output!

All you need to do is provide your own options, and format will use your preferences instead:

For a complete example, check out the [`FormatWithOptions.elm` in the examples folder](https://github.com/ryannhg/date-format/blob/master/examples/FormatWithOptions.elm).
values.type: DateFormat.FormatOptions -> List.List DateFormat.Token -> Time.Zone -> Time.Posix -> String.String

values.name: hourFixed
values.comment:
Get the hour of the 12-hour day, fixed to two places.

Examples: `00, 01, 02, ... 11, 12`

values.name: hourMilitaryFixed
values.comment:
Get the hour of the 24-hour day, fixed to two places.

Examples: `00, 01, 02, ... 22, 23`

values.name: hourMilitaryFromOneFixed
values.comment:
Get the hour of the 24-hour day, starting from one, fixed to two places.

Examples: `01, 02, ... 23, 24`

values.name: hourMilitaryFromOneNumber
values.comment:
Get the hour of the 24-hour day, starting from one.

Examples: `1, 2, ... 23, 24`

values.name: hourMilitaryNumber
values.comment:
Get the hour of the 24-hour day.

Examples: `0, 1, 2, ... 22, 23`

values.name: hourNumber
values.comment:
Get the hour of the 12-hour day.

Examples: `0, 1, 2, ... 11, 12`

values.name: minuteFixed
values.comment:
Get the minute of the hour, fixed to two places.

Examples: `00, 01, 02, ... 58, 59`

values.name: minuteNumber
values.comment:
Get the minute of the hour.

Examples: `0, 1, 2, ... 58, 59`

values.name: monthFixed
values.comment:
Get the numeric value of the month, fixed to two places.

Examples: `01, 02, 03, ... 11, 12`

values.name: monthNameFirstThree
values.comment:
Get the name of the month, but just the first three letters.

Examples: `Jan, Feb, Mar, ... Nov, Dec`

values.name: monthNameFull
values.comment:
Get the full name of the month.

Examples: `January, February, ... December`

values.name: monthNumber
values.comment:
Get the numeric value of the month.

Examples: `1, 2, 3, ... 11, 12`

values.name: monthSuffix
values.comment:
Get the numeric value of the month, with a suffix at the end.

Examples: `1st, 2nd, 3rd, ... 11th, 12th`

values.name: quarterNumber
values.comment:
Get the numeric value for the quarter of the year.

Examples: `1, 2, 3, 4`

values.name: quarterSuffix
values.comment:
Get the numeric value for the quarter of the year, with a suffix.

Examples: `1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th`

values.name: secondFixed
values.comment:
Get the second of the minute, fixed to two places.

Examples: `00, 01, 02, ... 58, 59`

values.name: secondNumber
values.comment:
Get the second of the minute.

Examples: `0, 1, 2, ... 58, 59`

values.name: text
values.comment:
Represent a string value

    formatter : Zone -> Posix -> String
    formatter =
        DateFormat.format
            [ DateFormat.hourMilitaryFixed
            , DateFormat.text ":"
            , DateFormat.minuteFixed
            ]

When given a [`Zone`](/packages/elm-lang/time/latest/Time#Zone) and [`Posix`](/packages/elm-lang/time/latest/Time#Posix), this will return something like `"23:15"` or `"04:43"`

values.name: weekOfYearFixed
values.comment:
Get the numeric value for the week of the year, fixed to two places.

Examples: `01, 02, 03, ... 51, 52`

values.name: weekOfYearNumber
values.comment:
Get the numeric value for the week of the year.

Examples: `1, 2, 3, ... 51, 52`

values.name: weekOfYearSuffix
values.comment:
Get the numeric value for the week of the year, with a suffix at the end.

Examples: `1st, 2nd, 3rd, ... 51st, 52nd`

values.name: yearNumberLastTwo
values.comment:
Get the year, but just the last two letters.

Examples: `70, 71, ... 29, 30`

name: DateFormat.Relative

aliases.name: RelativeTimeOptions
aliases.comment:
Options for configuring your own relative message formats!

For example, here is how `someSecondsAgo` is implemented by default:

    defaultSomeSecondsAgo : Int -> String
    defaultSomeSecondsAgo seconds =
        if seconds < 30 then
            "just now"
        else
            toString seconds ++ " seconds ago"

And here is how `inSomeHours` might look:

    defaultInSomeHours : Int -> String
    defaultInSomeHours hours =
        if hours < 2 then
            "in an hour"
        else
            "in " ++ toString hours ++ " hours"
aliases.type: { someSecondsAgo : Basics.Int -> String.String, someMinutesAgo : Basics.Int -> String.String, someHoursAgo : Basics.Int -> String.String, someDaysAgo : Basics.Int -> String.String, someMonthsAgo : Basics.Int -> String.String, someYearsAgo : Basics.Int -> String.String, rightNow : String.String, inSomeSeconds : Basics.Int -> String.String, inSomeMinutes : Basics.Int -> String.String, inSomeHours : Basics.Int -> String.String, inSomeDays : Basics.Int -> String.String, inSomeMonths : Basics.Int -> String.String, inSomeYears : Basics.Int -> String.String }

values.name: relativeTime
values.comment:
This function takes in two times and returns the relative difference!

Here are a few examples to help:

    relativeTime now tenSecondsAgo ==  "just now"
    relativeTime now tenSecondsFromNow ==  "in a few seconds"

    relativeTime now fortyThreeMinutesAgo == "43 minutes ago"

    relativeTime now oneHundredDaysAgo == "100 days ago"
    relativeTime now oneHundredDaysFromNow == "in 100 days"

    -- Order matters!
    relativeTime now tenSecondsAgo ==  "just now"
    relativeTime tenSecondsAgo now ==  "in a few seconds"

values.name: relativeTimeWithOptions
values.comment:
Maybe `relativeTime` is too lame. (Or maybe you speak a different language than English!)

With `relativeTimeWithOptions`, you can provide your own custom messages for each time range.

(That's what `relativeTime` uses under the hood!)

You can provide a set of your own custom options, and use `relativeTimeWithOptions` instead.
